docs.lead_paragraph: Lydia Siegel ran the Boston Marathon last month and credits some of her success to the group she meets on Tuesday evenings in Central Park. ''It's a lot easier in the freezing rain to meet up with a group,'' said Ms. Siegel, a 27-year-old research assistant at Mount Sinai Medical Center. ''When people have similar goals, it makes it much more fun, and easier to train.'' Judging from the growing numbers of people running in groups, it looks as if the loneliness of the long-distance runner may be a thing of the past. Group marathon training is expanding across the country and running groups, health clubs, coaches and personal trainers are becoming instrumental in providing safe and successful venues for long-distance training.
docs.abstract: Group marathon training is expanding across country; running groups, health clubs, coaches and personal trainers are becoming instrumental in providing safe and successful venues for long-distance training; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the anxious, stressed-out traveler, the Nob Hill Lambourne, a hotel in San Francisco that caters to business travelers, offers an unusual way to decompress: the front desk will arrange for a session with the hotel's psychologist. The hotel, owned by Joie de Vivre Hospitality, started the service in February 1998. Though only a few guests have taken advantage of it, the Hotel Acqua, also owned by Joie de Vivre, is scheduled to open in Mill Valley, Calif., in August, and will offer therapy sessions as well. Dr. Charmian Anderson, the Lambourne's in-house psychologist who has a private practice in Mill Valley, said she pitched the idea to the hotel's parent company, calculating that ''business people are getting used to services that are speedier and speedier, so why not 'quick' therapy?''

headline.main: Maids, Bellhops and Now, a Psychologist

docs.abstract: Nob Hill Lambourne, San Francisco hotel, offers guests services of a psychologist; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dame Cicely Saunders is considered by many to be the world's foremost expert in the care of the dying. In 1967, she opened St. Christopher's Hospice in London, the first research and teaching hospice. Her vision of a place where people could die with dignity, surrounded by family and treated by specialists in end-of-life care, spread around the world and helped spawn a new medical discipline, palliative care. Dr. Saunders, now 80, still goes to work every day and lives around the corner from the hospice that she founded. She was in New York recently to deliver a lecture at Mount Sinai Medical Center. In an interview, she spoke about her life and her philosophy of death. Q. For the last 50 years you've been involved in caring for the dying. Tell me about your life before that.

headline.main: Reflecting On a Life Of Treating The Dying

docs.lead_paragraph: Can you get the blood out of someone while it is still blue? Do cats and dogs get sick from second-hand smoke? These are typical questions from children in two schools in rural Vermont who were part of a Dartmouth Medical School study that looked at E-mail communication between children and doctors in training. The study also examined how children responded to computer-mediated communication.

headline.main: Children Get a Direct Line to the Doctor

docs.abstract: Children in two schools in rural Vermont have E-mail communications with doctors in training at Dartmouth Medical School, and results are beneficial for both sides (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Internet grows, so does the amount of health information available on line. But the sheer volume of information available on the Web does not equal a speedy, or accurate, search. To give order to the chaos of the Web, a handful of health care organizations have put their imprimaturs on information-rich Web sites accessible to anyone with a modem. While many medical centers use Web sites to advertise practical information like hours, resources and the latest research, others consider themselves full-fledged digital publishers, in the business of educating patients as much as promoting themselves.

headline.main: Hospitals Reaching New Patients On Line

docs.abstract: Growing number of medical centers and hospitals are providing health information and medical news to patients and people by means of the Internet; many medical centers use Web sites to advertise practical information like hours, resources and latest research, but others consider themselves full-fleged digital publishers, in business of educating patients as much as promoting themselves; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Having completed the first two phases of treatment for an early breast cancer -- a lumpectomy and six weeks of radiation therapy -- I have now begun the third and, in a way, the most exciting phase: five years of daily treatment with the drug tamoxifen. Unlike traditional cancer chemotherapy, tamoxifen does not kill cells and does not cause nausea and hair loss. Tamoxifen is more like a growth regulator. It is an estrogen-like compound that acts in the breast as an antiestrogen, preventing the natural hormone from stimulating the growth of breast cancer cells.

headline.main: Round 3 in Cancer Battle: A 5-Year Drug Regimen

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column gives update on her battle with breast cancer; reports that having undergone lumpectomy and six weeks of radiation therapy, she has now begun third and, in a way, most exciting phase: five years of daily treatment with drug tamoxifen; drawing illusrates how tamoxifen works (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The 10 men on the videotape look earnest enough. Each appears for two minutes, stating his opinions on an important social issue -- capital punishment, for example -- then explaining to an ''interrogator'' why he thinks as he does and how long he has held his views. The task of the person watching the video is to tell which of the men are lying and which are telling the truth.

headline.main: To Tell the Truth, It's Awfully Hard to Spot a Liar

docs.abstract: Psychologists and researchers find that most people do poorly at identifying liars, while a small group of people are spectacularly good at spotting lies; the latter do not rely on any single clue to tell them if someone is lying, but rather notice and interpret clusters of verbal and nonverbal signals that liars give out; cartoons (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1974, a doctor named Victor Esch was on a beach when he saw a lifeguard pull an unconscious man from the water. The guard tried to resuscitate the man, but was unsuccessful and declared him dead. Dr. Esch stepped in and asked if he could try something else. The lifeguard said yes, and Dr. Esch performed the Heimlich maneuver.

headline.main: Double Duty for a Lifesaving Move

docs.abstract: Heimlich maneuver, technique used to prevent choking to death, can be effective for purging water from lungs of drowning victims; drawings (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Based on a sampling of mercury levels in canned tuna, a coalition of environmental and health care groups has written a report urging pregnant women to avoid the fish entirely and advised mothers of preschoolers to serve up no more than one tuna salad sandwich a week. Although Federal guidelines were used to gauge risk, the Food and Drug Administration questioned the report's findings, calling them very suggestive, very preliminary and highly uncertain. docs.lead_paragraph: In 1951, pediatricians in Sydney, Australia, were puzzled by the death of a 10-month-old boy. The child had been screaming and vomiting for 30 hours, and doctors believed that he had a systemic infection or meningitis. But it was neither. Peering into a standard microscope at tissues from the boy's autopsy, Dr. Ralph Douglas Kenneth Reye found no evidence of infection. Instead, he noticed distinct liver and brain damage of a type that he had never seen. Over the next 11 years at the Royal Alexandra Hospital for Children, Dr. Reye identified 20 more cases of what his colleagues nicknamed Reye's syndrome. The doctors suspected the damage had resulted from a toxin they could not identify.

headline.main: Tale of Triumph on Every Aspirin Bottle

docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Douglas Reye, Australian physician who in 1950's identified fatal child's disease that came to be known as Reye's syndrome; two decades passed before American epedemiologists linked Reye's syndrome and use of aspirin to control fevers among children with viral infections, particularly influenza and chickenpox; Reye died in 1977; photo (L)
